docs.snippet: A suburban Detroit shopping center was evacuated on Saturday following a smash-and-grab robbery, but police said the scene was later secured.

headline.print_headline: Police Investigate Robbery That Prompted Evacuation of Mall
headline.main: Police Investigate Robbery That Prompted Evacuation of Mall

docs.snippet: Don’t be confused by false fliers, online pranks or websites that exist to deceive voters.

headline.main: The Hoaxes, Fake News and Misinformation We Saw on Election Day

docs.snippet: Japan's first lady has visited Pearl Harbor in Hawaii for the first time to pay tribute to the victims of the Japanese attack 75 years ago.

headline.print_headline: Japanese First Lady Pays Tribute at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii
headline.main: Japanese First Lady Pays Tribute at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii

docs.snippet: A West Virginia man accused of sexually assaulting a 9-month-old girl who later died from her injuries was charged on Thursday with first-degree murder.

headline.print_headline: West Virginia Man Charged With Raping, Murdering Nine-Month-Old Girl
headline.main: West Virginia Man Charged With Raping, Murdering Nine-Month-Old Girl

docs.snippet: A U.S. pastor who has made anti-gay comments is being deported, Botswana's government announced Tuesday, shortly after he spoke on local radio and called the people killed in the June shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando "disgusting."

headline.print_headline: Botswana Says to Deport US Pastor Who Made Anti-Gay Comments
headline.main: Botswana Says to Deport US Pastor Who Made Anti-Gay Comments

docs.snippet: Make it a priority to be human again — to work hard and to rest hard without worrying that we’ll fail at life if we rest, a financial planner writes.

headline.main: Let 2017 Be the Year of Working Hard and Resting Hard

docs.snippet: One theory about the six-second video app’s demise says it was dead weight for its owner, Twitter, which is struggling to become profitable.

headline.main: Vine Is Closing Down, and the Internet Can’t Stand It

docs.snippet: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
docs.abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

docs.snippet: Around 2,000 Hungarians protested in Budapest on Saturday against the closure of the country's leading leftist newspaper Nepszabadsag, saying press freedom was under threat.

headline.print_headline: Thousands Rally After Hungary's Leading Leftist Newspaper Unexpectedly Shuts
headline.main: Thousands Rally After Hungary's Leading Leftist Newspaper Unexpectedly Shuts
